docs.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency released a report today indicating that a proposed Clean Air Act standard on carbon monoxide was based in part on questionable, perhaps falsified, research. The research was performed in the 1970's by Dr. Wilbert S. Aronow, now director of cardiovascular research for the Creighton University Medical Center in Omaha. Last year, after the Food and Drug Administration charged him with falsifying test results, Dr. Aronow signed an agreement with the agency in which he promised to conduct no more testing of experimental drugs without special permission. Dr. Aronow said by phone that his research on carbon monoxide was accurate and a report on a review of his work was full of errors. The new carbon monoxide standard, scheduled to have been put into effect in the next few weeks, would essentially maintain the current rule stating that the average permissible amount of the gas in the air is 9 parts per million in any eight-hour period. This standard would allow a specific area to exceed this level once a year. The proposal would also have reduced the maximum carbon monoxide in the air in any one hour to 25 parts per million from the current level of 35 parts per million.

headline.main: CARBON MONOXIDE STUDY IS FLAWED, E.P.A. IS TOLD

docs.lead_paragraph: William Lindeman, one of eight counselors working on the Cocaine Hot Line at the drug-abuse unit in Fair Oaks Psychiatric Hospital, told a caller that he had to make his wife realize she was addicted to cocaine and that it was destroying their marriage. ''Tell her you're going to leave her, that you don't want to stay around and watch her kill herself,'' Mr. Lindeman said. ''Tell her that you love her and that when she wants help, you'll come back. That's the approach you've got to use.''
